.Net_Developer.question: What is overloading?
.Net_Developer.answer: When two or more methods in the same class have the same name but different parameters.
.Net_Developer.option1: When two or more methods in the same class have the same parameters but different name.
.Net_Developer.option2: When the method signature (name and parameters) are the same in the superclass and the child class
.Net_Developer.option3: When the method signature (name and parameters) are different in the superclass and the child class

.Net_Developer.question: What is overriding?
.Net_Developer.answer: When the method signature (name and parameters) are the same in the superclass and the child class
.Net_Developer.option1: When two or more methods in the same class have the same name but different parameters
.Net_Developer.option2: When the method signature (name and parameters) are different in the superclass and the child class
.Net_Developer.option3: When two or more methods in the same class have the same paramters but different name.

.Net_Developer.question: What is public modifier?
.Net_Developer.answer: means that it can be accessed by any class in any assembly, which includes the class itself.
.Net_Developer.option1: means it can only be accessed by the class itself, or accessed by a class that inherits it and that class can be in any assembly
.Net_Developer.option2: means it can be accessed by the class itself or by any class in the assembly but can't be accessed at all outside of the assembly unless by the class itself (i.e. it is a partial class)
.Net_Developer.option3: means that it can only be accessed by the class itself

.Net_Developer.question: What is IEnumerable?
.Net_Developer.answer: is a list or a container which can hold some items. You can iterate through each element. You can not edit the items like adding, deleting, updating, etc. instead you just use a container to contain a list of items. It is the most basic type of list container
.Net_Developer.option1: derives from IEnumerable and extends it’s functionality to add, remove, update element in the list. ICollection also holds the count of elements in it and we does not need to iterate over all elements to get total number of elements
.Net_Developer.option2: extends ICollection. An IList can perform all operations combined from IEnumerable and ICollection, and some more operations like inserting or removing an element in the middle of a list.
.Net_Developer.option3: generates a LINQ to SQL expression that is executed over the database layer. Instead of the generating a Func<T, bool> like the ones above, IQueryable generates an expression tree and gives Expression<Func<T, bool>> that is executed over the database layer to get data set.
